items.author: Joshua Rothkopf
items.content: A staggering political drama that could put you in mind of the intimate sweep of Bernardo Bertolucci, Incendies feels like a mighty movie in our midst.

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: The movie is a bumpy road of twists that leads to a revelation that has the shock and force of Greek tragedy.

items.author: David Edelstein
items.content: The movie doesn't quite jell, but you'll feel its sting for hours.

items.author: Stephen Farber
items.content: Although the film runs more than two hours, the story is so compelling and the production so beautifully controlled that we are gripped by the characters' quest right up to the shocking end of the story.

items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: A devastating mystery thriller from Quebec filmmaker Denis Villeneuve that grabs you hard and won't let go.

items.author: Eric Kohn
items.content: The climax is a little too clever and far-fetched-an unnecessarily neat finale for a movie that works fine when dealing in broad strokes, some of which are nothing short of masterful.

items.author: Ed Schied
items.content: Azabal is superb, conveying Nawal's fiery presence, determination and mounting bitterness. The impressive cast includes non-professionals from Jordan, where Incendies was filmed.

items.author: Peter Debruge
items.content: Incendies vaults Denis Villeneuve to the status of serious director.

items.author: Tasha Robinson
items.content: While the film will likely stick with viewers, it's ultimately a tossup what they'll remember most: the stunning buildup, or the massive letdown.

items.author: Mark Holcomb
items.content: Nawal's travails are more in the vein of a Latin American soap opera than Greek tragedy, and Jeanne and Simon's climactic, genuinely god-awful discovery plays like artistic sleight-of-hand rather than the profoundly tautological revelation it aspires to be.
